questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks have an air pressure level of:
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal should be:
questions.answerA: Pressed down quickly with both feet.
questions.explanation: When braking, push the pedal down gradually to ensure that the vehicle comes to a smooth, safe stop.

questions.question: To check the automatic transmission fluid level in some vehicles, the vehicle:
questions.answerD: May have to be left running.
questions.explanation: For some vehicles, you may need to leave the engine running to be able to check its automatic transmission fluid level.

questions.question: Steering that feels heavy is often a sign of:
questions.explanation: If steering begins to feel heavy, it is likely that one of your front tires has failed. If you feel a change to your steering, you should exit the road as quickly as is safely possible and check your tires.

questions.question: One way to avoid becoming an aggressive driver is to:
questions.answerA: Talk on your cell phone while driving.
questions.answerC: Set realistic expectations regarding travel time.
questions.explanation: To help avoid frustration, which can lead to aggressive driving behavior, you should begin a trip with realistic expectations about your travel time. Plan ahead to allow time for potential traffic delays. Other strategies to help prevent aggressive driving behavior include driving an appropriate speed and keeping a reasonable following distance; avoiding making gestures at other drivers; and keeping your hands on the steering wheel.

questions.question: When students are boarding a school bus, the driver should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Check all mirrors for students rushing toward the bus.
questions.answerB: Count the number of students at the bus stop and ensure all have boarded.
questions.answerC: Allow student to board in pairs.
questions.explanation: When approaching a bus stop, a school bus driver should count the number of students waiting and ensure that they all board the bus. The driver should check their mirrors for any students who may be running to the stop. Students should board slowly in a single-file line.

questions.question: The inside rearview mirror is used to:
questions.answerB: See potential hazards on the road.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.explanation: The overhead inside rearview mirror in a school bus is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: The inside rearview mirror of a school bus is used to:
questions.answerB: See potential hazards on the road.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.answerD: See in front of the bus.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: When dropping off students at a school, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Secure the bus by turning off the engine.
questions.answerB: Leave the key in the ignition, if leaving the driver’s compartment.
questions.answerC: Read a book while students unload.
questions.explanation: When unloading students at a school, a bus driver must secure the bus by turning off the engine. If they must leave the driver's compartment, they should remove the key from the ignition. The driver must supervise the unloading process.

questions.question: As a general rule, student safety is best maintained by:
questions.answerB: Letting some students evacuate the bus.
questions.answerC: Letting students evacuate the bus and scatter.
questions.explanation: In most emergency or crisis situations, students will be safest and easiest to keep under control if they remain on the school bus. Generally, students should be kept on the bus as long as it does not expose them to unnecessary risks or injury.

questions.question: At a passive railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: The decision to proceed rests with each driver.
questions.answerB: The decision to proceed should be based on a control device.
questions.answerC: The decision to proceed should be based on surrounding vehicles.
questions.answerD: The decision to proceed is left to passengers in each vehicle.
questions.explanation: Passive railroad crossings are not controlled by any traffic control devices. At such crossings, it is entirely a driver's responsibility to determine when it is safe to cross the tracks.

questions.question: A school bus must be evacuated if:
questions.answerA: The bus has stalled in winter weather conditions.
questions.answerB: The air conditioning system has broken.
questions.answerC: There is any imminent danger of collision.
questions.explanation: During emergency situations, it is usually safest for students to remain on a school bus. Evacuations are mandatory if the bus has stalled on railroad tracks, if the bus is on fire or there is a threat of fire, or if there is a hazardous materials spill. Students should be evacuated any time there is imminent danger of collision.

questions.question: When asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass the parking space while backing, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.answerD: Back into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the right of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: A school bus stop:
questions.answerA: Can be added by the driver if there is a need.
questions.answerB: Should be voted on by the students.
questions.answerC: May change, depending on weather conditions.
questions.answerD: Should be established by the proper school district authorities.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should not alter the location of a bus stop without written authorization of the appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a placarded vehicle, you should always:
questions.answerB: Stop within five feet of the tracks.
questions.answerC: Change gears while on the tracks.
questions.answerD: Change lanes while on the tracks.
questions.explanation: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a transit bus, school bus, or placarded vehicle, special procedures apply. Before crossing, stop your vehicle within 50 feet of, but not less than 15 feet from, the nearest rail. Activate your four-way flashers while crossing. Do not stop, change gears, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is proceeding across the tracks.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, what is considered an encroachment?
questions.answerA: The vehicle crossing over an exercise boundary line.
questions.answerB: A driver executing a single pull-up.
questions.answerC: A driver placing the vehicle in neutral and applying the parking brake.
questions.answerD: The vehicle stalling while the driver shifts gears.
questions.explanation: An encroachment during the basic vehicle control skills test is when an exercise boundary line is touched or crossed by any portion of the applicant's vehicle. Every encroachment will be counted as an error.

questions.question: If a tornado is approaching and the bus is evacuated, where should students go?
questions.explanation: If students are evacuated due to a school bus being in the direct path of a sighted tornado, the driver should lead them to shelter in a nearby building. If no such shelter is available, the driver should escort them to a nearby ditch or culvert. They should avoid areas that may be subject to flash flooding and should be far enough from the bus that it would not fall on them if it tipped over.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be score you on specific driving maneuvers as well as on your general driving behavior. You must drive in a safe and responsible manner; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and not cause an accident or commit a moving violation.

questions.question: The area to the left of a school bus is considered especially dangerous to students because:
questions.answerA: The sun’s reflection obscures the left side of the bus.
questions.answerB: Passing vehicles are located to the left of the bus.
questions.answerC: It is difficult to see the left side of any bus.
questions.answerD: There is no door on the left side of the bus.
questions.explanation: While all sides of a school bus have danger zones, the left side is particularly hazardous to students due to the presence of passing vehicles.

questions.question: When checking the power steering fluid during a vehicle inspection, you will need to do each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Show where the power steering fluid dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Check for adequate power steering fluid.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the power steering fluid level is above the full mark.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the power steering level is above the refill mark.
questions.explanation: When checking the power steering fluid during the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to indicate where the power steering fluid dipstick is located and show that there is an adequate amount of power steering fluid in the engine compartment. The fluid level must be above the refill mark.

questions.question: When students are being picked up by a school bus:
questions.answerA: The students should wait at a designated bus stop.
questions.answerB: The driver should pick up students whether or not they are at the designated bus stop.
questions.answerC: The parents should choose where the bus stop will be located.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should load and unload students only at designated stops that have been approved by appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: When operating a school bus, mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.explanation: It is critical to the safe operation of a school bus that mirrors be properly adjusted. Always check each mirror before operating the bus.

questions.question: In a school bus, where is the overhead inside rearview mirror located?
questions.answerA: Above the windshield on the driver’s side of the bus
questions.answerB: Above the door on the passenger side of the bus
questions.answerC: Above the emergency door in the rear
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is mounted directly above the windshield on the driver’s side of the bus. Its purpose is to allow the driver to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: Crossover mirrors help a school bus driver see:
questions.answerC: The left side of the bus.
questions.answerD: Vehicles in front of the bus.
questions.explanation: Crossover mirrors are used to help a driver see the danger zone area directly in front of a school bus, as well as the danger zone areas to the left and right sides of the bus, including the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: When driving a school bus, mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.explanation: You should always check the adjustment of all your mirrors before operating a school bus.

questions.question: ABS helps you:
questions.answerB: Keep the wheels from locking up.
questions.answerC: Count the number of students boarding the bus.
questions.explanation: An Ant-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps stop a vehicle's wheels from locking up during hard brake applications.

questions.question: A post-trip inspection should include all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Looking for articles left on the bus.
questions.explanation: After completing a trip, a school bus driver should do an inspection in which they check for sleeping students; belongings left on the bus; open windows or doors; any mechanical or operational issues with the bus; and damage or vandalism.

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to result in the most student deaths per year?
questions.answerA: Students loading and unloading a school bus
questions.answerD: Accidents in which drivers ignore traffic signals or signs
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year while getting on or off school buses than while riding as passengers on board school buses.

questions.question: If a driver cannot account for a student after the student has exited the bus, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Secure and leave the bus to look for the student.
questions.answerB: Assume the student has safely exited the bus.
questions.answerC: Walk to the back of the bus to see if the student got back on.
questions.answerD: Ask another student if they've seen the student.
questions.explanation: During unloading, if a school bus driver cannot account for a student outside of the bus, they should secure the bus and check for the missing student around and underneath the bus.

questions.question: When stopping to pick up students, a bus driver should:
questions.answerB: Place the vehicle in first gear.
questions.answerD: Place the vehicle in third gear.
questions.explanation: When stopping to pick up students, a school bus should be put in park. If the transmission does not have a park shift point, the vehicle should instead be placed in neutral.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should make sure that:
questions.answerC: The grooved pedal surface has not been smoothed out.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: Where is the overhead inside rearview mirror located?
questions.answerA: Above the windshield on the driver’s side of the bus
questions.answerB: Above the door across from the driver
questions.answerC: Above the emergency door in the rear
questions.explanation: The overhead inside rearview mirror of a school bus should be mounted directly above the windshield on the driver’s side of the vehicle. It should be used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: When boarding a school bus, students should:
questions.explanation: Students should board a school bus slowly and in a single-file line. For safety, boarding students should use the handrail.

questions.question: When exiting your vehicle, you:
questions.answerA: Must maintain four points of contact with the vehicle.
questions.answerB: May turn to face the road before your exit is complete.
questions.answerC: Must be facing away from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: The inside rearview mirror of a school bus is used to:
questions.answerB: See potential hazards on the road.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.answerD: See in front of the bus.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: Your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: Exactly where the examiner has instructed it to be.
questions.answerB: Within five feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerD: Within two feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: If a school bus needs to be evacuated, passengers should :
questions.answerA: Always exit through the rear door.
questions.answerC: Always exit through the front door.
questions.explanation: When preparing to evacuate a school bus, the driver must quickly determine which of the bus's exits is safest for passengers to use.

questions.question: About how many seconds in advance of a bus stop should warning lights be activated?
questions.explanation: If a school bus is equipped with alternating amber warning lights, they must be activated at least 200 feet, or about five to ten seconds, before the stop.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the right. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: If you must back up at a student pick-up point, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up before the students load the bus.
questions.answerB: Let the students load the bus before backing up.
questions.answerC: Let half of the students load the bus and then back up to meet the second half.
questions.explanation: If you must back up a school bus at a student pick-up point, do not put the bus in reverse until all students have boarded. Watch for late-comers at all times.

questions.question: If you must back up at a student pick-up point, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up before the students board the bus.
questions.answerB: Let the students board the bus and then back up.
questions.answerC: Let half the students board the bus and then back up toward the other half of the students.
questions.answerD: Tell the students to wait at the stop and then back toward the stop.
questions.explanation: If you must back up a school bus at a student pick-up point, be sure to pick up all students before you begin backing up. When backing, it is especially important to keep an eye out for latecomers.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Develop your own route to show off your driving skills.
questions.answerB: Listen to directions from the examiner.
questions.answerC: Bring a passenger to ride with you.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must listen to and follow the directions given by the examiner. They will never ask you to drive in an unsafe manner.

questions.question: When students are boarding a school bus, the driver should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Let students know when it is safe to board.
questions.answerB: Count the number of students at the bus stop and ensure that all have boarded.
questions.answerC: Allow student to board in pairs.
questions.answerD: Check all mirrors for students rushing toward the bus.
questions.explanation: Students should always board a school bus in a single-file line.

questions.question: Crossover mirrors help the driver see:
questions.answerC: The left side of the bus.
questions.explanation: Crossover mirrors are used to help a driver see the danger zone area directly in front of a school bus. The mirrors should also display the danger zone areas to the left and right sides of the bus, including the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without an accident.
questions.answerD: Demonstrate that you can use your cell phone while driving.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must drive in a safe and responsible manner; wear your safety belt; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and complete the test without any accidents or moving violations.

questions.question: ____ is responsible for properly labeling hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials properly. It is a good idea for the driver to ensure the materials are properly labeled.

questions.question: How do you label a hazardous material if the proper label will not fit on the material's package?
questions.answerA: The label may be placed on a tag securely attached to the package.
questions.answerB: A scannable QR code may instead be attached to the package.
questions.answerC: The HazMat label should be reduced in size to fit on the package.
questions.answerD: The label may be pasted to the wall of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If a hazardous materials label will not fit on a package, it may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials should always be loaded away from heat sources. Many materials become more hazardous if their temperatures increase.

questions.question: If transporting explosives, you may leave your vehicle unattended:
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be:
questions.explanation: Shipping papers for hazardous materials should always be easily accessible. When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be left on the driver's seat.

questions.question: Hazardous materials should be loaded and unloaded:
questions.explanation: Many hazardous materials become more dangerous when exposed to heat. Hazardous materials should be loaded and unloaded away from heat sources.

questions.question: How is a hazardous materials warning presented?
questions.answerB: By wrapping the package in orange
questions.answerC: By placing the item away from other cargo and covering it with a sign
questions.explanation: Signs are placed on the outside of vehicles and bulk packages to warn drivers and others about hazardous materials. These diamond-shaped signs are known as "placards."

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle:
questions.answerB: May only be moved in an emergency.
questions.answerC: May be driven if the cargo is not radioactive.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that lacks the proper placards for any hazardous materials on board may not be driven, except as necessary to protect life and property in an emergency.

questions.question: If you apply for a HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a check through which agency?
questions.explanation: To obtain an original or renewed hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass a Transportation Security Administration (TSA) background check.

questions.question: To know which placards to use, you need to know:
questions.answerA: The hazard classes of the materials.
questions.answerB: The types of containers holding the materials.
questions.explanation: To determine which hazardous materials placards to use, you must know the hazard class of the materials; the amount of hazardous materials being shipped; and the total weight of all classes of hazardous materials in the vehicle.

questions.question: An explosive material is most likely categorized as a ____ hazard.
questions.explanation: Class 1 hazardous materials are typically items that present certain explosion or fire hazards.

questions.question: Flammable gases are categorized as ____ hazards.
questions.explanation: Flammable gases are assigned to hazardous materials Class 2.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking but the driver does not have access to a phone, they should:
questions.answerA: Drive to a phone to alert emergency personnel.
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean-up facility.
questions.explanation: If a cargo of hazardous materials begins to leak, do not move your vehicle any more than safety requires. If you continue to drive, an even larger area will become contaminated. Instead, you should park your vehicle, secure it, stay with the vehicle, and contact the proper emergency personnel. If you do not have access to a phone, you should send someone else to get help.

questions.question: If a substance is transported in a reportable quantity, which letters must appear on the shipping paper and package?
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials are being transported in a reportable quantity in one package, the shipper must display the letters "RQ" on the shipping paper and package.

questions.question: What does a material’s hazard class reflect?
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material
questions.answerB: How quickly the material must reach its destination
questions.answerD: The country of origin of the materials
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will fall into one of nine hazard classes. The material's hazard class reflects its associated risks.

questions.question: In the Hazardous Materials Table, Column 2 lists:
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: A placard indicating hazardous materials is shaped like a:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are diamond-shaped.

questions.question: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on the shipping paper, which placard must be displayed?
questions.answerB: Poison Gas or Poison Inhalation Hazard
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on the shipping paper or package, you must display the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" or "Poison Gas" placards, as appropriate.

questions.question: How many identical placards must be placed on a vehicle?
questions.explanation: A placarded vehicle must have at least four identical placards: one on the front, one on the rear, and one on each side of the vehicle.

questions.question: A shipping paper:
questions.answerA: Is not needed for most shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Is required for all shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can be kept in a digital file.
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to provide proper shipping papers to communicate the risks of the materials.

questions.question: Before loading or unloading flammable liquids, the engine should be:
questions.explanation: Unless you must run the engine to operate a pump, you should always turn off the engine before loading or unloading flammable liquids.

questions.question: When transporting hazardous materials, placards:
questions.answerA: Should only be used with explosives.
questions.answerB: Should be used on all four sides of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should only be used by Class A licensed drivers.
questions.answerD: Should be used to reduce insurance rates.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards must be used on all four sides of a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerA: The shipping paper matches the marking and labels on packages.
questions.answerB: The shipping paper is written in code.
questions.answerC: All packages are labeled as poison.
questions.answerD: The shipping paper is not in the vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to compare a shipping paper to the applicable package markings and labels. Ensure that the shipper has included the correct basic description on the shipping paper and that it matches markings and labels.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.answerA: Any risks of fire or explosion.
questions.answerD: How many people should respond in the event of an accident.
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: If a leak is suspected in a cargo of radioactive material:
questions.answerA: The driver should go to the local fire department.
questions.answerB: The driver should pick up any loose pieces of the radioactive material.
questions.answerC: The driver should continue to carry the cargo, as long as they avoid touching the affected areas.
questions.answerD: The driver should not operate the vehicle until it has been cleaned.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting radioactive material and believe there is a leak or broken package in your cargo, you should tell your dispatcher or supervisor as quickly as possible. Do not touch or inhale the material. Do not use the vehicle until it has been cleaned or checked with a survey meter.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.explanation: Do not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded cargo tank used to transport Class 3 or Division 2.1 hazardous materials.

questions.question: Who must provide emergency response information?
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to provide emergency response information to drivers.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed, except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: If a product requires a "Poison Inhalation Hazard" placard, the placard must be used when transporting:
questions.answerA: More than 50 pounds of the product.
questions.answerB: More than 10 pounds of the product.
questions.answerD: The product in a non-sealed container.
questions.explanation: For applicable materials, the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" placard and the appropriate hazard class placard must always be displayed, even for small amounts of the materials.

questions.question: A hazardous material's identification number should appear:
questions.answerC: On a sticker near the material's shipping container.
questions.explanation: A material's ID number must appear on its accompanying shipping paper as well as on its packaging. It also must appear on cargo tanks and other bulk packaging.

questions.question: If you are transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you may notify other drivers:
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
questions.answerD: By keeping the driver's side door open.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the road while you are transporting explosive materials, you must warn other drivers. Put out warning signals like reflective triangles or electric lights if you are carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives. Do the same if you are driving a tank used to transport Class 3 flammable liquids or Division 2.1 flammable gases, even if the tank is empty. If transporting flammable materials, do not use warning signals that could cause your cargo to catch fire.

questions.question: A person who is watching the loading or unloading of a tank must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Remain within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.answerD: Know the hazards of the materials involved.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: The person loading a tank with hazardous materials must be all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Aware of the hazards associated with the materials.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: If corrosive materials leak in the trailer, the trailer should be:
questions.explanation: Parts of a vehicle that have been exposed to a corrosive material must be thoroughly washed with water.

questions.question: Who must mark and label the materials for shipping?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for correctly labeling and marking them. The driver should make sure that the shipper properly labeled and marked the materials before beginning a trip.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials. They must supply any necessary placards.

questions.question: Shippers must label hazardous materials. If an item is smaller than its label, how should the item be labeled?
questions.answerA: The item may be tied together with other hazardous materials and labeled with a sheet of paper on the outside of the bundle.
questions.answerB: The label may be attached to a tag that is securely attached to the package.
questions.answerC: The item may be marked with a large orange dot.
questions.answerD: The item may be placed in a box displaying a warning label.
questions.explanation: Shippers must place diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on most packages of hazardous materials. If the label won't fit on the package, it can be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: If "Inhalation Hazard" appears on a shipping paper, the shipper should provide which placard?
questions.answerB: Poison Gas or Poison Inhalation Hazard
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on the shipping paper or package, you must display the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" or "Poison Gas" placards, as appropriate.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Drive to find a phone to alert emergency personnel
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean up facility
questions.answerC: Park the vehicle and contact emergency personnel
questions.explanation: In the event of a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, do not continue to drive any longer than is necessary for safety. Continuing to drive would result in a larger area becoming contaminated. Instead, park the vehicle, secure the area, stay with the vehicle, and send someone to get help.

questions.question: If you're transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you should notify other drivers:
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down while you are transporting explosives and you need to use warning signals, use reflective triangles or red electric lights. Never use burning signals, such as flares or fuses, when transporting explosives.

questions.question: How is a hazardous materials warning presented?
questions.answerB: By wrapping the package in orange
questions.answerC: By placing the item away from other cargo and covering it with a sign
questions.explanation: Signs are placed on the outside of vehicles and bulk packages to warn drivers and others about hazardous materials. These diamond-shaped signs are known as "placards."

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed, except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: On a shipping paper describing both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may be identified by being:
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper includes information about both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous items must be clearly identified on the paper. They may be entered first, highlighted in a contrasting color, or identified with an "X" placed before the shipping description.

questions.question: If a product requires a "Poison Inhalation Hazard" placard, the placard must be used when transporting:
questions.answerA: More than 100 pounds of the product.
questions.answerB: More than 50 pounds of the product.
questions.answerD: The product in a leaking container.
questions.explanation: For applicable materials, the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" placard and the appropriate hazard class placard must always be displayed, even for small amounts of the materials.

questions.question: When loading hazardous materials, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Load the materials away from heat.
questions.explanation: When loading hazardous materials, do not use hooks or tools that could damage containers or other packaging.

questions.question: How often do hazardous materials employees need to be trained?
questions.answerB: At least once every three years
questions.explanation: Employees who work with hazardous materials must be trained and tested at least once every three years.

questions.question: The only way to effectively check your tire pressure is:
questions.answerC: By pushing on the tire to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: Placarded vehicles must carry fire extinguishers with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must carry a fire extinguisher with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: During a cargo fire, opening the trailer doors may actually cause the fire to expand because doing so:
questions.answerB: Changes the temperature of the trailer.
questions.answerC: Provides more moisture to the trailer.
questions.explanation: When experiencing a cargo fire, it may be a bad idea to open the doors to the trailer. Doing so allows oxygen to enter the area, potentially causing the fire to flare up and expand.

questions.question: Placards showing the type of hazardous materials in a vehicle are usually which shape?
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the package must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages containing liquid containers should display arrows pointing in the correct upright direction. These packages should be placed facing the correct direction.

questions.question: Portable tanks:
questions.answerA: Cannot be removed from a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Are not permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Cargo tanks remain on a vehicle at all times, regardless of whether or not they are carrying cargo. Portable tanks are bulk packaging and are not permanently attached to a vehicle.

questions.question: Shippers package in order to ____ hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Shippers package hazardous materials in a way that is meant to completely contain the materials. Vehicles should be placarded to communicate the risk of the cargo.

questions.question: The identification numbers assigned to chemicals can be found:
questions.answerA: In the DOT Emergency Response Guide.
questions.answerC: In the Periodic Table of Elements.
questions.explanation: Information about hazardous chemicals is found in the Emergency Response Guide (ERG) provided by U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT). The ERG is indexed by the proper shipping names and identification numbers of substances.

questions.question: Containers of nitric acid should be:
questions.answerA: Stacked no more than two containers high.
questions.answerC: Loaded on top of other products.
questions.explanation: Nitric acid should not be stacked above any other product. Containers of nitric acid may be stacked, but no higher than two containers high.

questions.question: Regulations require hazardous materials employees to be trained and tested how often?
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials employees must be trained and tested at least once every three years. Drivers must learn the risks associated with hazardous materials and be able to properly respond to security threats.

questions.question: An explosive material is most likely categorized as a ____ hazard.
questions.explanation: Class 1 hazardous materials are typically items that present certain explosion or fire hazards.

questions.question: Hazardous materials laws are controlled by:
questions.explanation: Because of the risks presented by the nature of the materials, government on federal, state, and local levels may impose regulations on the transportation of hazardous materials.

questions.question: Identification numbers, shipping names, and hazard classes:
questions.answerA: Should be abbreviated on a shipping paper if a small piece of paper is being used.
questions.answerB: Should be abbreviated on a shipping paper to make them easier to read.
questions.answerC: Should not be abbreviated on a shipping paper.
questions.answerD: Should only be abbreviated on a shipping paper if the abbreviations are easy to understand.
questions.explanation: Identification numbers, shipping names, and hazard classes must never be abbreviated when listed on a shipping paper. The only exception to this is if the abbreviation is specifically authorized in the hazardous materials regulations.

questions.question: Be sure you are always driving so your vehicle can stop:
questions.answerA: Within 10 feet of your current position.
questions.answerB: Within 1,000 feet of your current position.
questions.answerC: Within your view of the road ahead.
questions.explanation: Always be sure that you are driving in a manner that will allow your vehicle to come to a complete stop, if necessary, within the area of the road ahead that you are able to see.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it could cause the wheels to lock.
questions.answerC: You should turn the wheel very sharply.
questions.answerD: You should hold down the brakes until you are past the hazard.
questions.explanation: If you are turning to avoid a hazard, do not apply the brakes while you are turning. This could easily lock the wheels and create a skid.

questions.question: While driving a triple combination, keep the shut-off valves at the rear of the middle trailer in their:
questions.explanation: When operating a double or triple, the shut-off valves at the rear of last trailer should be closed. All other shut-off valves should be open.

questions.question: Brakes may get out of adjustment:
questions.explanation: Brakes can get out of adjustment quickly, especially if they are used to the point of overheating. Brake adjustment should be checked frequently.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a potential effect of drinking alcohol then driving?
questions.explanation: Driving errors that may be caused by alcohol-induced impairment include straddling lanes; quick, jerky starts; failure to signal or use lights; running stop signs and red lights; and improper passing. A driver's reaction time will become poor when they are under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Eating while driving is:
questions.answerA: A good way to save time.
questions.answerC: Acceptable if you are eating foods that are easy to eat.
questions.explanation: Smoking, eating, or drinking are distracting activities and should be avoided while you are driving. Instead, plan ahead and allow yourself time to stop to eat when making a lengthy trip.

questions.question: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels:
questions.answerA: Follow the same path as the front wheels.
questions.answerB: Follow a different path than the front wheels.
questions.answerC: Should not be a concern to the driver.
questions.explanation: When any vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is called off-tracking. The degree of off-tracking will be greater on long vehicles than on short vehicles.

questions.question: What does an air compressor do in an air brake system?
questions.answerA: It pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: It moves air to the back of the truck.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks. The air compressor is controlled by the air compressor governor.

questions.question: An open automobile window in cold weather may indicate that the driver is:
questions.answerC: Using the heat inside their vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' behaviors and identify clues that indicate when person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. A person driving with their window open in cold weather may be impaired.

questions.question: Most drivers are the least alert:
questions.explanation: Fatigue and lack of alertness are major hazards when driving at night. Most people are the least alert at night, especially after midnight.

questions.question: If driving so slowly that you could impede other drivers, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using your four-way flashers.
questions.explanation: If you must drive so slowly that you will impede the flow of traffic, you should turn on your four-way flashers to alert drivers behind you (as long as local laws allow the use of flashers).

questions.question: When checking tires, finding which of the following is not a cause for concern?
questions.answerB: Tread of at least 4/32 of an inch in the grooves on front tires
questions.answerC: Radial and bias-ply tires used together
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's tires, you should confirm that air pressure is neither too low nor too high; that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires; and that radial and bias-ply tires are not used together.

questions.question: If another driver is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerC: Increase the distance between you and the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, you should increase the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead. This will reduce your need to make sudden moves, and will also allow the tailgater more room to pass you. Speeding up when being tailgated is not advised because it may result in the tailgater continuing to follow you closely at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: When using a fire extinguisher to put out a fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay as far away as possible from the flames.
questions.answerC: Use any extinguisher on every type of fire.
questions.explanation: Stay as far away from a fire as possible and aim your fire extinguisher at the source or base of the fire, not at the flames. It may be appropriate to extinguish certain fires with water. If you are unsure of how to treat a specific fire, you should wait for  trained firefighters to arrive.

questions.question: When the wheels of a trailer lock up:
questions.explanation: A trailer may swing out and strike other vehicles if its wheels lock up. This is especially likely with lightly-loaded trailers.

questions.question: When braking while pulling a trailer equipped with anti-lock brakes, you should:
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the brakes kick in.
questions.answerC: Brake as you would without anti-lock brakes.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination that is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would if the vehicle was not equipped with ABS.

questions.question: After a vehicle is started, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should stay on for several minutes.
questions.answerB: Should turn off within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Should stay on until manually turned off.
questions.explanation: After starting the engine, warning lights and buzzers should go out right away. If a light stays on, it usually indicates an issue with the vehicle.

questions.question: The air compressor is connected to the:
questions.explanation: The air compressor of an air brake system is connected to the engine through gears or a v-belt. The compressor may be air-cooled or cooled by the engine cooling system.

questions.question: When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that you:
questions.answerB: Make sure there is a large enough gap for your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Expect other drivers to make room for your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Let other drivers wave you into their lane.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more space on the road than other vehicles. When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that there is a large enough gap in traffic for you to safely do so.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment can only be checked properly if:
questions.answerC: The vehicle is on a slight incline.
questions.explanation: On a vehicle with one or more trailers, mirror adjustment can only be checked accurately if the trailers are straight. Mirror adjustment should be checked before the start of every trip.

questions.question: Before starting down a hill, you should:
questions.explanation: Always downshift before beginning to drive downhill. Take the hill at a speed that does not require you to overuse your brakes.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Check the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the tire tread depth is good.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the correct tire was changed.
questions.answerD: See if rocks have gotten into the tread.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, you should stop a short while later to re-check the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: When it is difficult to see, such as at dawn or dusk, what is the best way to make your vehicle more visible?
questions.explanation: In conditions of poor visibility (such as at dawn, at dusk, in rain, or in snow), you should turn on your low beam headlights to make your vehicle easier to see. Do not use your high beams when driving near other vehicles.

questions.question: When driving on a long downhill slope, you should brake by:
questions.answerB: Mostly using the brakes and occasionally downshifting.
questions.answerC: Downshifting and then using the brakes.
questions.explanation: When approaching a long downgrade, you should shift into a lower gear then use proper braking techniques. Using the brakes alone could cause them to overheat and fail. The braking power of the engine, which is maximized by being in a lower gear, will be the principal way of controlling your speed on a downgrade.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, belts in the engine compartment should be:
questions.answerC: Inspected only if they seem frayed.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, belts in the engine compartment should be checked for tightness and excessive wear.

questions.question: What can the “crack-the-whip” effect do?
questions.explanation: The "crack-the-whip" effect can cause a trailer to turn over during a lane change. To avoid this phenomenon, drivers should make lane changes at slow, safe speeds.

questions.question: When stopping in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Veer your trailer to the right and stop.
questions.answerC: Veer your trailer to the left and stop.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line but will still allow you to turn if necessary.

questions.question: When visually checking a coupling device, you should:
questions.answerA: Look for mud on the fifth wheel.
questions.answerB: Make sure the kingpin is polished.
questions.answerC: Make sure there is a space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.
questions.answerD: Make sure the locking jaws are closed on the kingpin.
questions.explanation: When performing a visual check of coupling devices, you should make sure there is no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel. Ensure that the locking jaws are securely closed around the shank of the kingpin.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of retarder?
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. The four basic types of retarders are exhaust, engine, hydraulic, and electric.

questions.question: When nearing a construction worker who is close to the road, you should:
questions.answerD: Wait until the construction is complete before proceeding.
questions.explanation: In work zones, you should drive at the posted speed limits. Reduce your speed even further when workers are on or near the road.

questions.question: When stopping a manual transmission vehicle, what should you do when the engine is close to idle?
questions.explanation: When stopping a vehicle with a manual transmission, you should push in the clutch when the engine is close to idle.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Cannot be used on vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can help drivers see a larger area.
questions.explanation: Many large vehicles have curved, convex mirrors. Convex mirrors allow drivers to see a wider area than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they really are.

questions.question: A tractor protection valve is:
questions.answerA: A device that keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak.
questions.answerC: A device that controls fuel levels.
questions.answerD: A device that allows the battery to recharge efficiently.
questions.explanation: On combination vehicles with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer develop a bad leak or break away from the tractor.

questions.question: Using an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps to provide additional control during hard braking, but does not necessarily shorten a vehicle's stopping distance.

questions.question: When driving, mirrors should be used:
questions.answerA: Only when there may be a problem.
questions.explanation: It is essential that you are aware of what is surrounding your vehicle at all times. You should make a habit of regularly checking your mirrors while driving.

questions.question: While driving downhill, you should brake until you reach a speed that is ____ below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: While driving downhill, you should hold down the brake pedal until your vehicle reaches a speed 5 mph below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal. Repeat this process.

questions.question: The weight of a truck:
questions.answerA: Usually has no impact on stopping distance.
questions.answerB: Is a major factor affecting stopping distance.
questions.answerC: Is not as important as the type of cargo in determining stopping distance.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's weight is an important factor affecting its stopping distance. The heavier a vehicle is, the more work the brakes will need to do to bring it to a complete stop.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly, before other vehicles can enter into the lane.
questions.answerB: Move slowly in case another vehicle is in the lane.
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly. If there is a vehicle in the other lane that you did not see before beginning to move, they will have more time to react to your vehicle.

questions.question: Looking far ahead of your vehicle when driving is:
questions.answerA: Discouraged because the road ahead is not as important as your current location.
questions.answerB: Encouraged to help you identify hazards as early as possible.
questions.answerD: Only encouraged when transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should scan the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of your vehicle. This will allow you to notice hazards as early as possible, giving you time to react to them appropriately.

questions.question: You should ____ if the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving.
questions.answerA: Stop where you are and park
questions.answerB: Exit the roadway as soon as safely possible
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: A trolley valve:
questions.answerB: Should only be used to test trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Should be used when parking uphill.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve (also referred to as the trolley valve or Johnson bar) is a mechanism that works the trailer brakes. It should only be used to test the brakes. Using it while the vehicle is being driven could cause a skid. Never use the trailer hand valve while parking because doing so may release the air pressure  from the braking system, releasing the brakes that are holding the vehicle in place.

questions.question: Belts in the engine compartment should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine, check the belts for tightness and excessive wear. The amount of "give" that is safe for each belt in a given engine will vary, so learn what is appropriate for your vehicle.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer:
questions.answerA: You should not back up in a straight line.
questions.answerB: You should not correct drift until you are very far off course.
questions.answerC: You should pull up to reposition the vehicle as needed.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, you should pull up to reposition your vehicle as needed.

questions.question: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, your vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of the road.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.explanation: Factors that can affect stopping distance include your vehicle's speed, its weight, and the traction provided by the road surface.

questions.question: While driving:
questions.answerA: Creating a text is not permitted, but reading a text is.
questions.answerB: Creating a text is permitted, but reading a text is not.
questions.answerC: Neither creating nor reading a text is permitted.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving a CMV is prohibited. "Texting" is defined as manually entering text into, or reading text from, an electronic device.

questions.question: If the brakes “pull” to one side or the other when you use them, it's a sign that:
questions.answerB: The brakes need to be checked.
questions.answerD: The brakes have too much stopping power.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle "pulls" to one side when braking, you may have brake trouble. If there is an issue with your brakes, you should fix the issue before driving. Operating an unsafe vehicle is against federal and state laws.

questions.question: To help prevent a rollover, cargo should be:
questions.answerA: Placed as high as possible inside a trailer.
questions.answerB: Placed as low as possible inside a trailer.
questions.answerC: Placed on the driver’s side of a trailer.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is top-heavy, it is more likely to roll over. The weight of cargo should be positioned as low in a trailer as possible to minimize this risk.

questions.question: If unsure if a trailer is equipped with ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Try driving on a slippery surface and see if ABS kicks in.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies built on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). This will be indicated by the presence of a yellow malfunction lamp. You can determine if older trailers have ABS by checking under the trailers for ECU and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: Liquid surge occurs in:
questions.answerC: Tanks that have not been used for a period of time.
questions.explanation: Surge results from the movement of liquid in tanks that are partially filled.

questions.question: A Class 1 hazardous material is:
questions.explanation: Explosives are placed in hazardous materials Class 1.

questions.question: An exhaust system should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting an exhaust system, you should verify that parts of the system are not loose, broken, or missing. The system's parts must be properly mounted and should not be rubbing against moving parts of the vehicle.

questions.question: A steering wheel should be held:
questions.answerB: With one hand, keeping the other hand free for other tasks.
questions.answerC: With one hand at a time, alternating between hands.
questions.answerD: At the base of the wheel.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should be held firmly with both hands, positioned on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: If a leak is suspected in a cargo of radioactive material:
questions.answerA: The driver should go to the local fire department.
questions.answerB: The driver should pick up any loose pieces of the radioactive material.
questions.answerC: The driver should continue to carry the cargo, as long as they avoid touching the affected areas.
questions.answerD: The driver should not operate the vehicle until it has been cleaned.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting radioactive material and believe there is a leak or broken package in your cargo, you should tell your dispatcher or supervisor as quickly as possible. Do not touch or inhale the material. Do not use the vehicle until it has been cleaned or checked with a survey meter.

questions.question: To use the controlled braking method, you should:
questions.answerB: Apply your brakes as firmly as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.explanation: Controlled braking is the method of applying a vehicle's brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels. A driver should keep steering wheel movements very small if braking while using this method.

questions.question: The most important reason to do a pre-trip inspection is that it helps ensure safety.
questions.explanation: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is to ensure the safety of yourself and others on the road.

questions.question: Roads are especially slippery when it first begins to rain because:
questions.answerB: The fresh rain mixes with oil on the roadway.
questions.answerC: The water has nowhere to go.
questions.explanation: Roads are particularly slippery when it first begins to rain. The water mixes with oil drippings on the road that have not yet washed away, creating a slippery and dangerous mixture.

questions.question: A sign indicating a maximum safe speed:
questions.answerA: Is suggesting a driving speed, but vehicles may travel faster than the posted speed.
questions.answerB: Is suggesting a speed limit to be followed only by vehicles weighing more than 26,000 pounds.
questions.answerC: Should be followed and no vehicle should travel faster than the posted speed.
questions.explanation: You should never exceed the speed shown on a "Maximum Safe Speed" sign.

questions.question: Tires of mismatched sizes:
questions.answerA: Can be used only on a front axle.
questions.answerB: Can be used only on a trailer's axles.
questions.explanation: Tires on the same vehicle should all be equally sized. Ensure your tires are not mismatched when inspecting your vehicle.

questions.question: With your low beam headlights turned on, you should be able to see about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights allow you to see about 250 feet ahead of your vehicle. When driving at night, adjust your speed so that you will be able to stop in the distance illuminated by your headlights.

questions.question: A thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces is called:
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet. You should be very careful when temperatures are below freezing and the road looks wet.

questions.question: Hazardous materials should be loaded and unloaded:
questions.explanation: Many hazardous materials become more dangerous when exposed to heat. Hazardous materials should be loaded and unloaded away from heat sources.

questions.question: Front-to-back surge is usually very strong in:
questions.explanation: Smooth bore tanks, also known as unbaffled tanks, contain nothing to slow the movement of liquid and are likely to be affected by front-to-back liquid surge.

questions.question: When driving in hot weather:
questions.answerA: The air pressure in tires will decrease.
questions.answerB: The engine oil can help to keep the engine cool.
questions.explanation: Because air pressure increases as air expands in the heat, it is important to monitor your tire pressure when driving in very hot weather. To prevent the engine from overheating, there must be an adequate amount of oil in the engine, as well as enough water and antifreeze in the cooling system. Antifreeze is helpful for the engine in both hot and cold weather.

questions.question: If required, ____ identical placards must be placed on a vehicle.
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, a vehicle must display four identical placards. A placard should be placed on the front, on the rear, and on both sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: In very hot weather, tires should be checked regularly because:
questions.answerB: Air pressure may increase with the temperature.
questions.answerC: The tread wears down extra quickly.
questions.explanation: Air expands as it gets warmer, so the air pressure in your tires could reach dangerously high levels while being used in very hot weather. If this happens, stop and let your tires cool. Do not let air out of the tires, as this could result in the pressure dropping to an unsafe level once the tires cool down.

questions.question: The National Response Center must be notified of an incident resulting in any of the following, except:
questions.explanation: The National Response Center must be notified of any incident that results in death; hospitalization; $50,000 or more in estimated property damage; an evacuation of the general public or closure of a major transportation route/facility for more then one hour; fire, breakage, spillage, or suspected contamination involving radiation, bacteria, or toxins. Additionally, if the carrier judges the situation to be so serious that it should be reported, it should be reported.

questions.question: When a tire goes flat, you may hear a loud bang. The truck will be affected:
questions.answerC: Only if the damaged tire is near the front of the truck.
questions.answerD: Only if the truck is hauling a load.
questions.explanation: There may be a delay of a few seconds between the sound of a tire failing and the time that the vehicle is affected by the tire failure. Because of the short delay, a driver may initially believe that the sound came from another vehicle.

questions.question: Mirrors should be checked:
questions.answerB: When changing lanes, but only when other vehicles are nearby.
questions.answerC: When changing lanes, but only if it is dark outside.
questions.explanation: Always check for traffic in your mirrors before changing lanes. Frequent mirror checks should be a part of your normal scanning routine.

questions.question: If you are turning left where there are two available turning lanes:
questions.answerA: It is better to take the rightmost lane.
questions.answerB: It does not matter which lane you use.
questions.answerC: It is better to take the leftmost lane.
questions.explanation: If making a left turn where there is more than one available turn lane, you should always choose to take the rightmost lane. Large vehicles often have to swing right to make left turns, so it is safer for you to have other left-turning traffic to your left. This will allow you to have the best possible view of other turning vehicles and will lower the risk of your vehicle colliding with them.

questions.question: Move over laws require a driver approaching a stopped emergency vehicle to:
questions.answerA: Move into a lane that is not next to the stopped vehicle.
questions.answerC: Move into the far portion of their lane.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle using its flashing lights is stopped on the side of a multilane road, move over laws require drivers to vacate the lane directly next to the vehicle, if possible. If a driver cannot move over safely, they must slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: Hydroplaning:
questions.answerB: Usually happens when vehicles are traveling faster than 65 mph.
questions.answerC: Can occur with a minimal amount of water on the roadway.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be a large amount of water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: Who is responsible for identifying the hazard class of materials being shipped?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for identifying the product's identification number; proper shipping name; hazard class; packing group; and correct packaging, labels, marking, and placards.

questions.question: If a driver is given a leaking package or shipment, they should:
questions.answerC: Leave it on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to refuse packages or shipments of hazardous materials if they contain leaks.

questions.question: To prevent a trailer from rolling over, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up when nearing a corner.
questions.answerC: Take on-ramps faster than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a rollover when driving a combination vehicle, you should keep the weight of the cargo as low to the ground as possible and drive slowly around turns.

questions.question: When approaching a vehicle for a pre-trip inspection, a driver should look under the vehicle:
questions.answerA: To see if the vehicle is on an incline.
questions.answerB: To see if there are any fresh fluids on the ground.
questions.answerC: To see if the vehicle is in a parking spot.
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle before an inspection, make note of its general condition and ensure that it is not damaged or leaning. Look under the vehicle for fresh leaks of oil, grease, or fuel. Check around the vehicle for hazards to movement, such as people, other vehicles, or low-hanging wires or tree limbs.

questions.question: When driving a tank vehicle with liquid cargo, the driver should:
questions.explanation: When driving with a tank of liquid, you should increase your following distance in order to reduce the need for sudden stops, thereby reducing the chance of liquid surge.

questions.question: If you doubt that you have enough space to safely drive under a bridge or sign, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are not certain that your vehicle will fit under overhead objects, you should slow down and take a different route, if possible.

questions.question: Eating while driving:
questions.answerA: Is a good way to maximize your time.
questions.answerC: Is a distraction to the driver.
questions.explanation: Eating while driving can be a dangerous distraction to the driver both because it diverts their attention away from the task at hand and requires them to remove a hand from the steering wheel.

questions.question: What is sleep debt?
questions.answerA: When you fall behind on sleep
questions.answerB: When you want to take a nap
questions.answerD: The amount of time it takes to get ready to drive after sleeping
questions.explanation: You can build up a "debt" of sleep if you do not sleep for adequate amounts of time. You can only catch up on the time that you "owe" by getting more sleep.

questions.question: If something is found to be unsafe during a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue with the trip and make an appointment with a mechanic after the trip is completed.
questions.answerB: Let a more experienced driver use the truck.
questions.answerD: Not use the items found to be unsafe, but may continue driving normally.
questions.explanation: If a pre-trip inspection reveals anything unsafe about your vehicle, you must get it repaired. It is illegal to operate an unsafe vehicle.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard:
questions.answerA: You should always steer to the left.
questions.answerB: You may be able to drive onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: You should steer sharply in one direction.
questions.explanation: In some emergencies, the best strategy for avoiding a hazard may be to drive onto the shoulder. Most shoulders are strong enough to support the weight of a large vehicle.

questions.question: When using a fire extinguisher on a fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close to the fire as possible.
questions.answerB: Stay as far away from the fire as possible.
questions.answerC: Aim the extinguisher at the top of the flames.
questions.answerD: Aim the fire extinguisher at the ground about two feet away from the fire.
questions.explanation: When using a fire extinguisher, you should stay as far away from the flames as possible and aim at the base of the fire.

questions.question: When going downhill, switching into a lower gear is an effective way to slow a vehicle.
questions.explanation: On a steep downgrade, you must use the engine's braking effect as your primary method of speed control. Be sure to decelerate and downshift appropriately before beginning to drive down the hill.

questions.question: Fueling a bus while passengers are on board is:
questions.answerB: Acceptable only on trips of more than 100 miles.
questions.answerC: Acceptable only if doing so is unavoidable.
questions.explanation: A bus should not be refueled while passengers are on board unless it is absolutely necessary to do so. In particular, a bus with riders on board should never be refueled inside an enclosed building.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS).

questions.question: When applying your brakes, the vehicle should:
questions.explanation: Your vehicle pulling to one side or the other while you are braking can indicate trouble with the brakes.

questions.question: The suspension system:
questions.answerA: Holds up the vehicle and its load.
questions.answerB: Keeps the load the proper distance behind the driver’s compartment.
questions.answerC: Maintains a safe distance between the vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerD: Lightens the load for the tires.
questions.explanation: The suspension system holds up a vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Faults in a vehicle's suspension system are extremely dangerous.

questions.question: A driver may not operate a CMV with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.04 percent.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to operate a CMV with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.04 percent or more. Operating a CMV while under the influence of alcohol will result in license disqualification.

questions.question: Noting the road speed is one way to determine when to upshift.
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: When starting an engine, warning lights and buzzers should:
